May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [#paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection] (1 items) Group: Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/members/cwrycraft/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=2&access_key=a0309d45a8a9ebe80959a6b6dbdf22b1] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fpaul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection%2Fnotifications%2F] c.collis [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/members/c-collis/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 1:09 am, May 5, 2014 

	Hi Grant: I’m also particularly looking forward to hearing and learning from teachers about their TEL experiences. I’m benefiting from the participation of many ’technologists’ here because this is their world and they have a wealth of resources and references to share. In practice, I find that sometimes technologists and teachers work at cross purposes: technologists are rightly more focussed on the tech and all the things it can do and how great it would be if we implemented it in our teaching; teachers are more focussed on the subject content and how it can be taught effectively, whether this involves TEL or not. Teachers sometimes feel beseiged by what they perceive as overzealous technologists bombarding them with things they need to add to their already full courses; technologists sometimes feel frustrated at what they perceive as stubborn academics who refuse to try new things that the technologists know could enhance their students’ learning experiences. I can see the frustrations of both groups (and I know the lines between these two groups are nowhere near as clear-cut as this post indicates). It wil be interesting to see how these two groups interact in this MOOC, or whetehr they are in fact identifiable as two groups in this environment. I’m learning from both. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00/members/cwrycraft/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

<div style="font-size:130%;">Your daily digest of group activity at <a href='http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00'>ocTEL 2014</a></div>

<li ><a href='#paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection'>Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection</a> (1 items)</li>
</ul>
<div style="font-size:120%; background-color:#F5F5F5; padding:3px; margin:20px 0 0; border-top: 1px #eee solid;">Group: <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00" name="paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection">Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection</a></div>
<div style="font-size:12px; margin-left:10px; color:#888;">To disable these notifications for this group click  <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/cwrycraft/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&#038;group=2&&utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00#038;access_key=a0309d45a8a9ebe80959a6b6dbdf22b1">unsubscribe</a> &#8211; change <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&#038;auth=1&&utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00#038;redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fpaul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection%2Fnotifications%2F">email options</a></div>
<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/c-collis/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00" title="c.collis">c.collis</a> posted a new activity comment: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 1:09 am, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">Hi Grant: I&#8217;m also particularly looking forward to hearing and learning from teachers about their TEL experiences. I&#8217;m benefiting from the participation of many &#8217;technologists&#8217; here  because this is their world and they have a wealth of resources and references to share. In practice, I find that sometimes technologists and teachers work at cross purposes: technologists are rightly more focussed on the tech and all the things it can do and how great it would be if we implemented it in our teaching; teachers are more focussed on the subject content and how it can be taught effectively, whether this involves TEL or not. Teachers sometimes feel beseiged by what they perceive as overzealous technologists bombarding them with things they need to add to their already full courses; technologists sometimes feel frustrated at what they perceive as stubborn academics who refuse to try new things that the technologists know could enhance their students&#8217; learning experiences. I can see the frustrations of both groups (and I know the lines between these two groups are nowhere near as clear-cut as this post indicates). It wil be interesting to see how these two groups interact in this MOOC, or whetehr they are in fact identifiable as two groups in this environment. I&#8217;m learning from both. </span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00">View</a></div>
<div class="ass-footer" style="margin:25px 0 0; padding-top:5px; border-top:1px #bbb solid;">You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014.</p>
<p>To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/cwrycraft/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__74&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:12+00:00">My Groups</a> where you can change your email settings for each group.</div>
<p></body></html></p> 

 ------------------ end of mail ------------------

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : dominic ennis <dominic.ennis@york.ac.uk>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [#paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection] (1 items) Group: Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/members/dominicennis/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=2&access_key=729478cb6c81e8aefe922acb441ea98c] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fpaul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection%2Fnotifications%2F] c.collis [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/members/c-collis/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 1:09 am, May 5, 2014 

	Hi Grant: I’m also particularly looking forward to hearing and learning from teachers about their TEL experiences. I’m benefiting from the participation of many ’technologists’ here because this is their world and they have a wealth of resources and references to share. In practice, I find that sometimes technologists and teachers work at cross purposes: technologists are rightly more focussed on the tech and all the things it can do and how great it would be if we implemented it in our teaching; teachers are more focussed on the subject content and how it can be taught effectively, whether this involves TEL or not. Teachers sometimes feel beseiged by what they perceive as overzealous technologists bombarding them with things they need to add to their already full courses; technologists sometimes feel frustrated at what they perceive as stubborn academics who refuse to try new things that the technologists know could enhance their students’ learning experiences. I can see the frustrations of both groups (and I know the lines between these two groups are nowhere near as clear-cut as this post indicates). It wil be interesting to see how these two groups interact in this MOOC, or whetehr they are in fact identifiable as two groups in this environment. I’m learning from both. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00/members/dominicennis/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__77&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:22+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group. 

	 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

<p><span style="color:#333;">Hi Grant: I&#8217;m also particularly looking forward to hearing and learning from teachers about their TEL experiences. I&#8217;m benefiting from the participation of many &#8217;technologists&#8217; here  because this is their world and they have a wealth of resources and references to share. In practice, I find that sometimes technologists and teachers work at cross purposes: technologists are rightly more focussed on the tech and all the things it can do and how great it would be if we implemented it in our teaching; teachers are more focussed on the subject content and how it can be taught effectively, whether this involves TEL or not. Teachers sometimes feel beseiged by what they perceive as overzealous technologists bombarding them with things they need to add to their already full courses; technologists sometimes feel frustrated at what they perceive as stubborn academics who refuse to try new things that the technologists know could enhance their students&#8217; learning experiences. I can see the frustrations of both groups (and I know the lines between these two groups are nowhere near as clear-cut as this post indicates). It wil be interesting to see how these two groups interact in this MOOC, or whetehr they are in fact identifiable as two groups in this environment.  From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : alvaller <alvaller@bond.edu.au>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [#enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel] (4 items) 
	* Higher education (general) [#higher-education-general] (1 items) Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/alvaller/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=4da0bfbfcd56bbc2239558cbbed3c582] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] Helen Whitehead [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/helenwhd/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] posted an update: at 10:52 am, May 4, 2014 

	Agree with those so far who say peer to peer enthusing on TEL is most likely to be a success in generating more interest in TEL. One way we do this is a monthly session in which we encourage staff to share what they do. These are recorded and added to our blog which is open to all. I also collect case studies – perhaps this group is one way to build a really good data bank of case studies we can all use to say ”Have you seen what Dr X and Professor Y have done in a similar context to yours…” – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/activity/p/3676/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:19 pm, May 4, 2014 

	We have a whole mix of ways. Lots of it can be explored here- where I’ve written about some of what we do on our external blog (just started).
http://passitonbloggers.wordpress.com/ – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:21 pm, May 4, 2014 

	It’s taken us time to get people on board and maintaining momentum is tricky but we’re getting there… Slowly but surely. It’s just a real culture change for everyone- a move away from hiding away all your great ideas and resources! – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] Nell C Rundle [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/nellcrundle/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 11:53 pm, May 4, 2014 

	What is your approach to collecting case studies? I have a sense that this approach to sharing practice is likely to be quite powerful in showcasing options and possibilities, but at my institution we have not really done well in collecting them in a coherent way, or sharing them on. I’d be very interested to know what approaches others have taken/take to first finding and ’collecting’ case studies, and secondly in sharing them effectively with a wider audience. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] Group: Higher education (general) [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/groups/higher-education-general/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/alvaller/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=17&access_key=0bbf831b707b4e5aa7b47ceed9cd4d83] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fhigher-education-general%2Fnotifications%2F] markofmarks [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/markofmarks/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] posted an update: at 12:21 am, May 5, 2014 

	I’m from Melbourne at Swinburne Uni, where we are expanding in the online space for L&T.
My background is an academic teaching in physiology and neuroscience, and I think that there are great opportunities and challenges for my students. Additionally the microcosm of the people joining and participating in this MOOC reflect some of the realities of my (and probably others’) experience in this realm.
Can we use what we experience here to improve our own practice? Yes. 

	From Alicia’s post, and having just participated in another MOOC a few weeks back, already I am impressed with the ease of group creation/joining/participation in this offering. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/activity/p/3748/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00/members/alvaller/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/markofmarks/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00" title="markofmarks">markofmarks</a> posted an update: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 12:21 am, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">I&#8217;m from Melbourne at Swinburne Uni, where we are expanding in the online space for L&amp;T.<br />
My background is an academic teaching in physiology and neuroscience, and I think that there are great opportunities and challenges for my students. Additionally the microcosm of the people joining and participating in this MOOC reflect some of the realities of my (and probably others&#8217;) experience in this realm.<br />
Can we use what we experience here to improve our own practice? Yes.</p>
<p>From Alicia&#8217;s post, and having just participated in another MOOC a few weeks back, already I am impressed with the ease of group creation/joining/participation in this offering.</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3748/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__79&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:26+00:00">View</a></div>

   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [#enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel] (4 items) Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/romieh/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=32c5edce22bb4c65914b70ff4ef7bec0] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] Helen Whitehead [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/helenwhd/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] posted an update: at 10:52 am, May 4, 2014 

	Agree with those so far who say peer to peer enthusing on TEL is most likely to be a success in generating more interest in TEL. One way we do this is a monthly session in which we encourage staff to share what they do. These are recorded and added to our blog which is open to all. I also collect case studies – perhaps this group is one way to build a really good data bank of case studies we can all use to say ”Have you seen what Dr X and Professor Y have done in a similar context to yours…” – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/activity/p/3676/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:19 pm, May 4, 2014 

	We have a whole mix of ways. Lots of it can be explored here- where I’ve written about some of what we do on our external blog (just started).
http://passitonbloggers.wordpress.com/ – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:21 pm, May 4, 2014 

	It’s taken us time to get people on board and maintaining momentum is tricky but we’re getting there… Slowly but surely. It’s just a real culture change for everyone- a move away from hiding away all your great ideas and resources! – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] Nell C Rundle [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/nellcrundle/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 11:53 pm, May 4, 2014 

	What is your approach to collecting case studies? I have a sense that this approach to sharing practice is likely to be quite powerful in showcasing options and possibilities, but at my institution we have not really done well in collecting them in a coherent way, or sharing them on. I’d be very interested to know what approaches others have taken/take to first finding and ’collecting’ case studies, and secondly in sharing them effectively with a wider audience. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00/members/romieh/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__80&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:28+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : kerr 63 <kerr.63@osu.edu>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Higher education (general) [#higher-education-general] (1 items) Group: Higher education (general) [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/groups/higher-education-general/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/members/jameskerr/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=17&access_key=48bcbf8baaf6ee793c4676a2f05b74d2] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fhigher-education-general%2Fnotifications%2F] markofmarks [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/members/markofmarks/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00] posted an update: at 12:21 am, May 5, 2014 

	I’m from Melbourne at Swinburne Uni, where we are expanding in the online space for L&T.
My background is an academic teaching in physiology and neuroscience, and I think that there are great opportunities and challenges for my students. Additionally the microcosm of the people joining and participating in this MOOC reflect some of the realities of my (and probably others’) experience in this realm.
Can we use what we experience here to improve our own practice? Yes. 

	From Alicia’s post, and having just participated in another MOOC a few weeks back, already I am impressed with the ease of group creation/joining/participation in this offering. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/activity/p/3748/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00/members/jameskerr/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group. 

	 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

<li ><a href='#higher-education-general'>Higher education (general)</a> (1 items)</li>
</ul>
<div style="font-size:120%; background-color:#F5F5F5; padding:3px; margin:20px 0 0; border-top: 1px #eee solid;">Group: <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/higher-education-general/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00" name="higher-education-general">Higher education (general)</a></div>
<div style="font-size:12px; margin-left:10px; color:#888;">To disable these notifications for this group click  <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jameskerr/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&#038;group=17&&utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00#038;access_key=48bcbf8baaf6ee793c4676a2f05b74d2">unsubscribe</a> &#8211; change <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&#038;auth=1&&utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00#038;redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fhigher-education-general%2Fnotifications%2F">email options</a></div>
<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/markofmarks/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00" title="markofmarks">markofmarks</a> posted an update: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 12:21 am, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">I&#8217;m from Melbourne at Swinburne Uni, where we are expanding in the online space for L&amp;T.<br />
My background is an academic teaching in physiology and neuroscience, and I think that there are great opportunities and challenges for my students. Additionally the microcosm of the people joining and participating in this MOOC reflect some of the realities of my (and probably others&#8217;) experience in this realm.<br />
Can we use what we experience here to improve our own practice? Yes.</p>
<p>From Alicia&#8217;s post, and having just participated in another MOOC a few weeks back, already I am impressed with the ease of group creation/joining/participation in this offering.</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3748/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00">View</a></div>
<div class="ass-footer" style="margin:25px 0 0; padding-top:5px; border-top:1px #bbb solid;">You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014.</p>
<p>To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jameskerr/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__81&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:30+00:00">My Groups</a> where you can change your email settings for each group.</div>
<p></body></html></p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : m s anderson <m.s.anderson@greenwich.ac.uk>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [#enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel] (4 items) Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/m_anderson_phd/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=01564c405204ea56cc4ed06cdf47226b] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] Helen Whitehead [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/helenwhd/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] posted an update: at 10:52 am, May 4, 2014 

	Agree with those so far who say peer to peer enthusing on TEL is most likely to be a success in generating more interest in TEL. One way we do this is a monthly session in which we encourage staff to share what they do. These are recorded and added to our blog which is open to all. I also collect case studies – perhaps this group is one way to build a really good data bank of case studies we can all use to say ”Have you seen what Dr X and Professor Y have done in a similar context to yours…” – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/activity/p/3676/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:19 pm, May 4, 2014 

	We have a whole mix of ways. Lots of it can be explored here- where I’ve written about some of what we do on our external blog (just started).
http://passitonbloggers.wordpress.com/ – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:21 pm, May 4, 2014 

	It’s taken us time to get people on board and maintaining momentum is tricky but we’re getting there… Slowly but surely. It’s just a real culture change for everyone- a move away from hiding away all your great ideas and resources! – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] Nell C Rundle [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/nellcrundle/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 11:53 pm, May 4, 2014 

	What is your approach to collecting case studies? I have a sense that this approach to sharing practice is likely to be quite powerful in showcasing options and possibilities, but at my institution we have not really done well in collecting them in a coherent way, or sharing them on. I’d be very interested to know what approaches others have taken/take to first finding and ’collecting’ case studies, and secondly in sharing them effectively with a wider audience. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00/members/m_anderson_phd/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__82&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:32+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

	Agree with those so far who say peer to peer enthusing on TEL is most likely to be a success in generating more interest in TEL. One way we do this is a monthly session in which we encourage staff to share what they do. These are recorded and added to our blog which is open to all. I also collect case studies – perhaps this group is one way to build a really good data bank of case studies we can all use to say ”Have you seen what Dr X and Professor Y have done in a similar context to yours…” – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00/activity/p/3676/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:19 pm, May 4, 2014 

	We have a whole mix of ways. Lots of it can be explored here- where I’ve written about some of what we do on our external blog (just started).
http://passitonbloggers.wordpress.com/ – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00] hannahtyreman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00/members/hannahtyreman/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__84&utm_campaign=2014-05-05T05:00:35+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 12:21 pm, May 4, 2014

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! c.collis posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	c.collis posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection 

	“As a result of thinking that through, I’ve come up with one new initiative: I’m going to invite one of the Learning Designers to attend each of my department’s monthly departmental meetings. The LD will have a standing agenda item each month: s/he will either give an update about a piece of tech that is working particularly well in our areas at the moment, and/or take questions from academic staff about tech ideas they have. Could be a neat way to bridge the sometimes gap between techs and academics, a way to get us working together.” 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/vearg/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=2&access_key=0df36c711d1b8cd569a10427e82d2a8d

	c.collis replied to one of your updates: 

	“As a result of thinking that through, I’ve come up with one new initiative: I’m going to invite one of the Learning Designers to attend each of my department’s monthly departmental meetings. The LD will have a standing agenda item each month: s/he will either give an update about a piece of tech that is working particularly well in our areas at the moment, and/or take questions from academic staff about tech ideas they have. Could be a neat way to bridge the sometimes gap between techs and academics, a way to get us working together.”

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : jennie swann <jennie.swann@aut.ac.nz>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] New message from Martin Hawksey 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] New message from Martin Hawksey !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Martin Hawksey sent you a new message: 

	Subject: Copy of entry badge text 

	“Hi – I spotted your comment to delete a TEL Explorer badge entry because of mis-posting. Here’s the text you submitted incase you want to reuse anywhere else: 

	You’re right, I think, about the difficulty of designing a course to meet such a diversity of expectations, but this approach does shift the responsibility for learning firmly towards the student. Heutagogy in action! Personally I’m looking forward to learning from the perspectives of others. Does anyone know how many have enrolled on this course so far? I may be missing something but I don’t yet have a picture of who’s here. Would be interested to know more. This is my fourth MOOC, all at the cMOOC end of the spectrum. I certainly felt pretty alienated during my first one in 2010. Little was done to facilitate dialogue. It was left up to us and try as I might I didn’t get any response to any of my postings. In both the last one I did, edcmooc, and this one there is a great deal more effort on this front. I wonder how intensive these few weeks are going to be for our facilitators. I get the impression that allowing for such a diversity of ways of communicating creates an enormous amount of work. I like the design though. I’m finding it pretty easy to find my way around. The only downside for me is that being on the other side of the planet means that synchronous things like webinars and the resulting Twitter conversations happen in the middle of my night, when I’m not at my sharpest! Am I missing out? I don’t know. Checking in first thing in the morning seems to work, even if I’m behind the ball in some of the faster conversations” 

	To view and read your messages please log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jswann/messages/ 

	———————
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jswann/settings/notifications/ 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=7545ec13a552c9045210abbf9a58db9b&id=116]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=7545ec13a552c9045210abbf9a58db9b] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Martin Hawksey sent you a new message:</p>
<p>Subject: Copy of entry badge text</p>
<p>&#8220;Hi &#8211; I spotted your comment to delete a TEL Explorer badge entry because of mis-posting. Here&#8217;s the text you submitted incase you want to reuse anywhere else:</p>
<p>You’re right, I think, about the difficulty of designing a course to meet such a diversity of expectations, but this approach does shift the responsibility for learning firmly towards the student. Heutagogy in action! Personally I’m looking forward to learning from the perspectives of others. Does anyone know how many have enrolled on this course so far? I may be missing something but I don’t yet have a picture of who’s here. Would be interested to know more. This is my fourth MOOC, all at the cMOOC end of the spectrum. I certainly felt pretty alienated during my first one in 2010. Little was done to facilitate dialogue. It was left up to us and try as I might I didn’t get any response to any of my postings. In both the last one I did, edcmooc, and this one there is a great deal more effort on this front. I wonder how intensive these few weeks are going to be for our facilitators. I get the impression that allowing for such a diversity of ways of communicating creates an enormous amount of work. I like the design though. I’m finding it pretty easy to find my way around. The only downside for me is that being on the other side of the planet means that synchronous things like webinars and the resulting Twitter conversations happen in the middle of my night, when I’m not at my sharpest! Am I missing out? I don’t know. Checking in first thing in the morning seems to work, even if I’m behind the ball in some of the faster conversations&#8221;</p>
<p>To view and read your messages please log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jswann/messages/</p>

To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/jswann/settings/notifications/</p>

	Moira Sarsfield wrote: 

	Thanks, James. This is a great tool, offering convenience for downloading and sharing. 

	Another benefit of the format is that the opening lines of each page/article are included in the listing. This made me more inclined to click on the links, rather than just having the title. 

	 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/readlists-from-readability/#post-10183

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : gandvbaxter <gandvbaxter@btinternet.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.5: Interesting examples of Technology Enhanced Learning 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.5: Interesting examples of Technology Enhanced Learning !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rachelhtan wrote: 

	 
<p class=”p1″>The use of Web 2.0 tools to engage students in learning is gaining prominence in education. However, the wide range of tools available for use can be daunting to a beginning user. Dr Lim from the NIE Learning Sciences & Technologies group shows how the process of digital curation using Diigo can help student teachers appraise and select appropriate technologies for integration into teaching and learning. The goal of digital curation, in this case, is to increase the student teachers’ knowledge of the pedagogical fit between digital media and the desired learning outcomes. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FWAVegXoG3Y&list=PLAf9SLWDu57BEwYoHCaoCGFjtuj2Erryx&feature=share&index=4</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-5-interesting-examples-of-technology-enhanced-learning/#post-10188 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3ec863f7572f4206e37d2334ae611de3] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rachelhtan wrote:</p>
<p>&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;p1&#8243;&gt;The use of Web 2.0 tools to engage students in learning is gaining prominence in education. However, the wide range of tools available for use can be daunting to a beginning user. Dr Lim from the NIE Learning Sciences &amp; Technologies group shows how the process of digital curation using Diigo can help student teachers appraise and select appropriate technologies for integration into teaching and learning. The goal of digital curation, in this case, is to increase the student teachers’ knowledge of the pedagogical fit between digital media and the desired learning outcomes. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FWAVegXoG3Y&amp;list=PLAf9SLWDu57BEwYoHCaoCGFjtuj2Erryx&amp;feature=share&amp;index=4&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-5-interesting-examples-of-technology-enhanced-learning/#post-10188</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : hellomrminiki <hellomrminiki@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.5: Interesting examples of Technology Enhanced Learning 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.5: Interesting examples of Technology Enhanced Learning !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rachelhtan wrote: 

	 
<p class=”p1″>The use of Web 2.0 tools to engage students in learning is gaining prominence in education. However, the wide range of tools available for use can be daunting to a beginning user. Dr Lim from the NIE Learning Sciences & Technologies group shows how the process of digital curation using Diigo can help student teachers appraise and select appropriate technologies for integration into teaching and learning. The goal of digital curation, in this case, is to increase the student teachers’ knowledge of the pedagogical fit between digital media and the desired learning outcomes. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FWAVegXoG3Y&list=PLAf9SLWDu57BEwYoHCaoCGFjtuj2Erryx&feature=share&index=4</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-5-interesting-examples-of-technology-enhanced-learning/#post-10188 

	———–

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rachelhtan wrote:</p>
<p>&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;p1&#8243;&gt;The use of Web 2.0 tools to engage students in learning is gaining prominence in education. However, the wide range of tools available for use can be daunting to a beginning user. Dr Lim from the NIE Learning Sciences &amp; Technologies group shows how the process of digital curation using Diigo can help student teachers appraise and select appropriate technologies for integration into teaching and learning. The goal of digital curation, in this case, is to increase the student teachers’ knowledge of the pedagogical fit between digital media and the desired learning outcomes. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FWAVegXoG3Y&amp;list=PLAf9SLWDu57BEwYoHCaoCGFjtuj2Erryx&amp;feature=share&amp;index=4&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-5-interesting-examples-of-technology-enhanced-learning/#post-10188</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : john kelly <john.kelly@banbury-bicester.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : ferridayr <ferridayr@cardiff.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=36720faac94f45ab0c38867b4d4a3ffd]

 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. <p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. 	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : hellomrminiki <hellomrminiki@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right.  ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : ed <ed@bremweb.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>
