	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203

	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3616010606e1545b3a54428db4cee7cb] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>
<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p> 

 ------------------ end of mail ------------------

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : belinda green <belinda.green@northampton.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———–

 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : matt <matt@mattsmeeth.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>

 ocTEL 2014

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203

May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus

	marcusod wrote:

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : cara saul <cara.saul@me.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	marcusod wrote: 

	Hi all 

	I’m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I’m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I’m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies. 

	I’m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing 

	Marcus 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>marcusod wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>I&#8217;m a journalism academic in a regional university just outside Sydney Australia but I&#8217;m currently seconded to the central learning teaching and curriculum unit to work on a university wide curriculum transformation project. I&#8217;m passionate about technology and multimedia in education because I believe it provides opportunities for exciting, active learning experiences and because I believe one of the obligations of any university is to produce digitally literate graduates. We get students to do essays for several reasons: we want them to engage with particular ideas, we want them to learn skills in critical analysis and argument and we want them to learn to write and communicate. Same with technologically enhanced tasks, the process and use of the technology is important: digital literacies are not just a by product of using technologies in the classroom in the same way that critical analysis is not just a by product of essay writing.  They are important pedagogical ends in their own right. These processes whether they are technological or traditional need to be attended to just as much as the disciplinary knowledge. So while we always need to choose the right technology for the right task technology is not JUST a tool it is integral to a complete experience of 21c learning of 21c literacies.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking forward to some lively discussions and sharing</p>
<p>Marcus</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10203</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Moira Sarsfield mentioned you in an update !

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : jennifer schneider <jennifer.schneider@newcastle.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	malmaley wrote: 

	Adding to Jennifer’s reflection .. so the old label “self directed learning” corresponds to “individual and autonomous” in this context. 

	<span class=”Apple-style-span”>For Jennifer’s flip-shocked students the change is perhaps too much from traditional systems of  “individual and directed” to “</span>individual and autonomous” <span class=”Apple-style-span”> .. perhaps there the role of technology could be to provide a framework to contextualise the learning rather than direct it, as a person (old fashioned teacher role) would.</span> 

	(technology like an invisible electric fence for the managed stock) 

	refer #10274 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10288 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33&id=266]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>malmaley wrote:</p>
<p>Adding to Jennifer&#8217;s reflection .. so the old label &#8220;self directed learning&#8221; corresponds to &#8220;individual and autonomous&#8221; in this context.</p>
<p>&lt;span class=&#8221;Apple-style-span&#8221;&gt;For Jennifer&#8217;s flip-shocked students the change is perhaps too much from traditional systems of  &#8220;individual and directed&#8221; to &#8220;&lt;/span&gt;individual and autonomous&#8221; &lt;span class=&#8221;Apple-style-span&#8221;&gt; .. perhaps there the role of technology could be to provide a framework to contextualise the learning rather than direct it, as a person (old fashioned teacher role) would.&lt;/span&gt;</p>
<p>(technology like an invisible electric fence for the managed stock)</p>
<p>refer #10274</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10288</p>

mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;

<![endif]–>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>Hi Jennifer,</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”><span style=”mso-spacerun: yes;”>               </span>I too have observed that when some students are confronted with the “wide open spaces” of self-directed learning, they can become overwhelmed and have difficulty in figuring out how to proceed.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>This may be because, as you suggest, that students are used to learning <span style=”mso-spacerun: yes;”> </span>as being comprised of very structured activities in which their role as learner was well defined.<span style=”mso-spacerun: yes;”>  </span>In self-directed learning, the “script” is completely changed; turned on its head even.<span style=”mso-spacerun: yes;”>  </span>So learners now have new roles, different roles and for many of these learners, there is no “script” that they can call upon to help them navigate the situation.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>I think it would be the same for any of us who went into a situation with expectations for norms that were not met. <span style=”mso-spacerun: yes;”> </span>We too would be disconcerted and there would be a period of transition as we learned to adjust to the “new normal”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>I suspect that, as instructors who are interested in promoting self-directed learning, we may find ourselves having to lead may learners through a ‘transition phase ‘ as they acclimatize to this learning approach.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>Best,</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>Kathy</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10339

&lt;/style&gt;<br />
&lt;![endif]&#8211;&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;Hi Jennifer,&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;&lt;span style=&#8221;mso-spacerun: yes;&#8221;&gt;               &lt;/span&gt;I too have observed that when some students are confronted with the “wide open spaces” of self-directed learning, they can become overwhelmed and have difficulty in figuring out how to proceed.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;This may be because, as you suggest, that students are used to learning &lt;span style=&#8221;mso-spacerun: yes;&#8221;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;as being comprised of very structured activities in which their role as learner was well defined.&lt;span style=&#8221;mso-spacerun: yes;&#8221;&gt;  &lt;/span&gt;In self-directed learning, the “script” is completely changed; turned on its head even.&lt;span style=&#8221;mso-spacerun: yes;&#8221;&gt;  &lt;/span&gt;So learners now have new roles, different roles and for many of these learners, there is no “script” that they can call upon to help them navigate the situation.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I think it would be the same for any of us who went into a situation with expectations for norms that were not met. &lt;span style=&#8221;mso-spacerun: yes;&#8221;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;We too would be disconcerted and there would be a period of transition as we learned to adjust to the “new normal”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I suspect that, as instructors who are interested in promoting self-directed learning, we may find ourselves having to lead may learners through a ‘transition phase ‘ as they acclimatize to this learning approach.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;Best,&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;Kathy&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10339</p>

<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Teresa MacKinnon replied to one of your comments !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Teresa MacKinnon replied to one of your comments: 

	“we could get started asynchronously and then sort out a hangout maybe later? what is your timezone?
Here’s a doc I have started: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dOe9h4zHCwlXq3Zouxz5vAcIcDuVFSfQbqEa1TT7YTQ/edit?usp=sharing
it is completely open to all to edit and improve. I guess we will all have different contexts so it is about capturing all the challenges and opportunities as they are seen by the whole group. All welcome, sign in to the google doc if you have an account.
I look forward to some computer-mediated interaction :)” 

	To view the original activity, your comment and all replies, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/language-teachers/forum/topic/hangout/

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Teresa MacKinnon replied to one of your comments:</p>
<p>&#8220;we could get started asynchronously and then sort out a hangout maybe later? what is your timezone?<br />
Here&#8217;s a doc I have started: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dOe9h4zHCwlXq3Zouxz5vAcIcDuVFSfQbqEa1TT7YTQ/edit?usp=sharing<br />
it is completely open to all to edit and improve. I guess we will all have different contexts so it is about capturing all the challenges and opportunities as they are seen by the whole group. All welcome, sign in to the google doc if you have an account.<br />
I look forward to some computer-mediated interaction :)&#8221;</p>
<p>To view the original activity, your comment and all replies, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/language-teachers/forum/topic/hangout/</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : john kelly <john.kelly@banbury-bicester.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>

 ocTEL 2014

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———–

<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>

	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>
<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : david <david@ALCHEMI.CO.UK>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———–

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : bali <bali@aucegypt.edu>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———–

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : hellomrminiki <hellomrminiki@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : sue bebbington <sue.bebbington@anu.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>

	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423</p>
