 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : ed <ed@bremweb.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>

	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : madhurakpradhan <madhurakpradhan@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———–

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : scott h t miller <scott.h.t.miller@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : matt <matt@mattsmeeth.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>

<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>

	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>
<p>Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting.</p>
<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>
<p>I have seen criticisms above about how staff not &#8216;engaging&#8217; with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited &#8211; besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea.</p>
<p>I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it.</p>
<p>I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : julie carrie <julie.carrie@uws.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423 

	———–

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>

<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 5, 2014



	rosemary.eaton wrote: 

	Hi all 

	Starting out a bit late on this.  Have scanned through some of the earlier posts and found it interesting. 

	I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don’t use it as I don’t really see the point. 

	I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it. 

	Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes – I wouldn’t know where to start with this. 

	I have seen criticisms above about how staff not ‘engaging’ with technology.  I use Moodle more than many within my circle of colleagues but this is still limited – besides posting handouts I do use forums, particularly for revision discussions, and also quizzes but I know there is a lot more that I could do.  I have attempted to encourage students to use Google Docs for assignment collaboration but found them to be resistant to the idea. 

	I agree with earlier comments about how does the use of technology enhance what we are doing and the debate about whether doing things like marking through Moodle is quicker/better and if not why are we doing it. 

	I am keen to learn more about the technologies that are available at no (or little cost) and ideas on how to integrate these in my teaching practice. 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10423

 <p>rosemary.eaton wrote:</p>
<p>Hi all</p>

<p>I have always thought of myself as someone who is quite comfortable with technology but I find the world of social media completely mystifying.  I have a personal Facebook account which I use a little for interaction with friends and a LinkedIn profile that I want to develop from a professional standpoint.  I do have a Twitter account but don&#8217;t use it as I don&#8217;t really see the point.</p>
<p>I have two twenty something year old boys who are constantly online in some way or another and see students in the classroom also online.  I feel that I need to understand more about this and how I can use it.</p>
<p>Someone posted above saying just ask a question in your class via Twitter by setting up a hashtag and see what happens after 10 minutes &#8211; I wouldn&#8217;t know where to start with this.</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : paul davis <paul.davis@tcat.ac.uk>  
 Subject : sal_chappell posted a new activity comment in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! sal_chappell posted a new activity comment in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	sal_chappell posted a new activity comment in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL 

	“Helen, I agree the monthly sessions are brilliant (and I’ve learnt loads!), but I still think we face the perennial problem of how we get new faces along to them. Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that’s absolutely necessary. If the “champions” are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don’t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these “champions” aren’t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn’t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful – we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples – it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That’s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start.” 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email
To change your email setting for this group, please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F 

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/citizendavis/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=e65f2d52414374b689ece541d095c04a

Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that&#8217;s absolutely necessary. If the &#8220;champions&#8221; are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don&#8217;t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these &#8220;champions&#8221; aren&#8217;t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn&#8217;t reach a wider audience.  ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : helen whitehead <helen.whitehead@nottingham.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] sal_chappell replied to one of your updates 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] sal_chappell replied to one of your updates !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	sal_chappell replied to one of your updates: 

	“Helen, I agree the monthly sessions are brilliant (and I’ve learnt loads!), but I still think we face the perennial problem of how we get new faces along to them. Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that’s absolutely necessary. If the “champions” are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don’t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these “champions” aren’t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn’t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful – we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples – it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That’s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start.” 

	To view your original update and all comments, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3676/ 

	———————
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/helenwhd/settings/notifications/

Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that&#8217;s absolutely necessary. If the &#8220;champions&#8221; are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don&#8217;t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these &#8220;champions&#8221; aren&#8217;t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn&#8217;t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful &#8211; we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples &#8211; it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That&#8217;s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start.&#8221;</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : jennifer schneider <jennifer.schneider@newcastle.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Jennifer, 

	I don’t know which sector you work in, but in schools (in the UK at least) so much of what children have to learn is dictated by the curriculum, and exam results are so important for both children AND schools that it can be very difficult to give children much autonomy most of the time. I have just been watching this video http://www.media.mit.edu/video/view/spring14-2014-04-24-4 which is an appreciation of Seymour Papert and his ideas, and the need to think about thinking about thinking (I think that I think that I think that I have the right). 50 years ago he was pushing for some of the same ideas. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10484 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33&id=341]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Jennifer,</p>
<p>I don&#8217;t know which sector you work in, but in schools (in the UK at least) so much of what children have to learn is dictated by the curriculum, and exam results are so important for both children AND schools that it can be very difficult to give children much autonomy most of the time.  I have just been watching this video http://www.media.mit.edu/video/view/spring14-2014-04-24-4 which is an appreciation of Seymour Papert and his ideas, and the need to think about thinking about thinking (I think that I think that I think that I have the right).  50 years ago he was pushing for some of the same ideas.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10484</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : john kelly <john.kelly@banbury-bicester.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac&id=345]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac]

 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.  In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond).  You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>
<p>My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic.  The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking.  Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511</p>

	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=e14af77a93d4708909a0a4a6c3a4b53b] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.  In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond).  You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>
<p>My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic.  The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking.  Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511</p>

	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : l woodland <l.woodland@cranfield.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=bfeebf955894a48d3a475d15b574146b]

 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.  In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond).  You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>
<p>My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic.  The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking.  Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.</p>

	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : mcjsa2 <mcjsa2@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.  In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond).  You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>
<p>My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic.  The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking.  Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511</p>

 <p>Tom Franklin wrote:</p>
<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.  In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond).  You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>
<p>My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic.  The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking.  Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———–

Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511

In other words, I wouldn&#8217;t start with the technology.  From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : matt <matt@mattsmeeth.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———–

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : julie carrie <julie.carrie@uws.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 5, 2014



	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	Rosemary, 

	you make some interesting points here. For me the critical question is always “what is the problem you are trying to solve?” or something like that. In other words, I wouldn’t start with the technology. Is there an area in your practice that you would like to improve (this could be anything from a conceptual difficulty that students have with an idea to getting them to take account of feedback you provide, to getting more students to ask questions in class and beyond). You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help. Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want. 

	My belief, from having watched a lot of technologies being introduced and then used badly or not at all is that starting with the technology is hugely problematic. The nearest to an exception to this I have seen is online assessment and marking. Many lecturers and teachers, and many students want better (whatever we might mean by that) feedback (or move to feedforward), and there are tools in many VLEs and stand alone tools like Grademark and Peermark that can be used for this. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10511 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

You can then think about how you might want to work on that area, and it may be that the use of technology can help.  Then it is a matter of finding the appropriate technology to achieve what you want.</p>

<p>Rosemary,</p>
<p>you make some interesting points here.  For me the critical question is always &#8220;what is the problem you are trying to solve?&#8221; or something like that.
